polytopes:
The purpose of this site is to give an introduction to toric varieties -- and to develop geometric intuition through an interactive 2D-polytope interface.

[[ex-poly-1|Click here]] to load a polytope, and click the lattice points to modify the given polytope.

A $\textit{polytope}$, $\Pi \subset \mathbb{R}^n$ is the convex hull of finitely many points.

Equivalently, a polytope is the intersection of finitely many half planes.

We restrict our attention to the convex hulls of lattice points $$\Lambda \subset \RR^2$$also known as $\textit{lattice polytopes}$. Equivalently, lattice polytopes are intersections of half-planes by forms in the dual lattice:$$\Lambda^\vee \subset {(\mathbb{R}^2)}^\vee.$$

To a polytope $\Pi\subset \mathbb{R}^n$ we associate a partially ordered set of $\textit{strata}$: $$\Sigma(\Pi) \subset \mathcal{P}(\Pi).$$Visibly, a stratum is either $\Pi$ or a polytope on the boundary of $\Pi$ (in our example, a vertex, edge or face). (Technically a stratum is a polytope which is the convex hull of a subset of extremal vertices.) The example in the lattice has

[center]({{1 + vertices + edges + faces}} {{"total strata"}}) = ({{faces|descr}})+({{edges|descr}})+({{vertices|descr}})+({{"1 empty stratum"}}).[/center]
rings:
Consider the triangle [[P2:rings]]. This is the simplest 2D polytope and corresponds to the projective plane.

$\textbf{The ring associated to a stratum}.$

To understand the coordinate rings of these polytopes, click on a vertex. The cone around this vertex defines a sub-monoid of the lattice (after translating the vertex to the origin): $$M \subset \Lambda.$$Working over a field $k$ we associate to $M$ the $\textit{monoid ring}$: $$k[M] = \left\{\sum a_i \chi^{m_i} \middle| m_i \in M, a_i \in k\right\}$$where elements are polynomials in $\chi^m$ for an element $m \in M$ and multiplication is defined by associativity and exponentiation rules.

Now to each vertex we have an associated ring, and by taking the spectrum of this ring we have an affine variety.
